certifications.name: Taking risks: ICH Q9 (R1) Quality Risk Management Certificate

message.text:
I'd argue with the notion that the average reading age for GMP staff is 9, but the graphic certainly paints a clear picture of why SOPs, Methods, Work Instructions, Policies etc should be regarded as documents to be referred to on a frequent basis, rather than "read and understood" every 2 years. 
GMP is far too important to be treated as a memory test.

“We’ve written SOPs and work instructions for everything, but people aren’t following them.”

Quality managers often fall into the trap of thinking that writing a procedure is all you need to do.

It isn’t. And here’s why.

The average reading age is 9.
Up to 20% of the population is dyslexic.
And if written information isn’t applied, 75% of it is forgotten within a week.

So those long, complex, read-and-sign SOPs covering absolutely everything related to a process?

They get skipped over, forgotten and ignored. And that’s an audit finding waiting to happen.

Instead, try this:

- Keep docs simple, brief and contextual
- Introduce imagery, presentations and even walkthrough videos alongside text
- Digitize them and put them in the cloud for easy, frequent access at the point of use
- Replace the one-time ‘doc deluge’ with just-in-time drip-feeds supported by your subject matter experts

With the end goal of safe and effective products always in mind, your SOPs and WIs should be tools for your staff to use, not markers for auditors to check.

Make them usable by the people who should be using them.

#qualitymanagement #lifescience

message.text:
Do you know how to breathe?

We all do it automatically every day and night, but we're you ever taught the best way?

I know I wasn't.

The Physiology of Breathing: A Delicate Balance

Breathing, or respiration, is a delicate ballet of gas exchange, where oxygen (O2) is inhaled and carbon dioxide (CO2) is expelled. This process is tirelessly choreographed by the respiratory system, with the diaphragm playing the lead role. When we inhale, the diaphragm contracts and moves downward, enlarging the thoracic cavity and allowing lungs to expand and fill with air. Upon exhaling, the diaphragm relaxes, pushing air out of the lungs. It's a cycle as rhythmic as the tides, yet far more rapid.

Free Radicals: The Unseen Villains

Every breath we take introduces oxygen into our bodies, a vital element for our survival. However, oxygen's interaction with our body's molecules can sometimes produce free radicals—unstable atoms that can damage cells, leading to inflammation and disease. Our bodies are equipped with antioxidants to neutralize these radicals, but excessive exposure, especially in polluted environments, can overwhelm these defenses.

The Alkaline Tide: Balancing the pH

Breathing also plays a pivotal role in regulating the body's pH level through the removal of CO2, a product of metabolism. CO2 is acidic in nature, and its removal is essential to maintain the blood's slightly alkaline pH (7.35 to 7.45). Altered breathing patterns can disrupt this balance; hyperventilation, for instance, expels CO2 too rapidly, raising blood pH (alkalosis), while shallow breathing retains CO2, lowering pH (acidosis). This delicate balance is crucial for enzyme functions and overall cellular health.

Shallow Breathing: The Modern Epidemic

Most people breathe shallowly, barely engaging their diaphragms, primarily due to a sedentary lifestyle and chronic stress. This suboptimal breathing fails to fully oxygenate the blood and remove CO2 efficiently, contributing to increased stress, reduced energy levels, and a predisposition to various health issues. It's as if we're sipping on life, rather than drinking deeply from its fountain.

Diaphragmatic Breathing: The Art of Deep Respiration

Diaphragmatic breathing, or deep belly breathing, is the antidote to the shallow breaths that plague modern existence. By engaging the diaphragm fully, this technique ensures efficient gas exchange, promotes relaxation by activating the parasympathetic nervous system, and improves oxygen delivery to tissues. It's akin to opening the windows wide in a stuffy room, allowing fresh air to circulate freely.

Breath Deserves Our Attention

Breath work is a powerful tool for managing stress, improving cognitive function, enhancing physical health, and fostering emotional resilience. Breath work offers a pathway to better health, acting as a bridge between the mind and body. It's a testament to the idea that sometimes, the most profound solutions are the simplest ones.

Follow @paulrpalmer

A fantastic summary of how your behaviours shape your future, often more than your technical abilities.

What does your "invisible PR" look like?? 

The small interactions you have with people have big implications on your "invisible PR".

Let me explain 👉🏽 We all have bad days, moody days and we don't know what someone is going through - but being kind can quite literally change the trajectory of your life. It will subtly nudge you in a different direction through favours, promotions and other types of recognition.

Being un-kind is a tax on your talent - it will weigh down your potential.

None of us imperfect human beings are going to be able to achieve perfect kindness at all times, including me.

However, if we all understand the value of it, to ourselves and others, hopefully we can try a little harder, every day, online and offline, to be a little kinder.

Do you agree? Like this post if so.
A startlingly stark question from Paul Palmer there for all wannabe QP's, "could you cope if you made the wrong decision and 100 people died?".

Anyone who tells you anyone can be a Qualified Person (QP) is just trying to sell you their training course.
Here’s the truth about how to decide if studying to be a QP is right for you, based on 20 years helping and guiding “potential” QP’s.
You can get a years experience then be a QP:

A Pharmacist straight out of university has no knowledge about manufacturing medicinal products.

Never go straight into a role you don’t understand, always get the experience and knowledge first.

As the QP you will be asked questions, these will be documented and any in investigation such as where someone died you are legally responsible and potentially liable

Always get experience in the area you would like to work in under the guidance of an experienced Qualified Person to understand whether it's the right career choice for you.

2. QPs are paid really well
The pay for being a QP is high in relation to other technical roles, but the responsibility is much higher.

Look at what the QP you work with actually does on a day to day basis, how late they work the pressure upon them.

There are good parts about being a QP, the salary, but also some you may not be willing to accept such as being on call 7 days a week 24 hours a day to make the decisions you are required to make.

Talk to QP's to get a better understanding about what is expected and make sure it matches your understanding.

3. Anyone can be a QP
It is possible for anyone with the right degree to become a QP, but is it right for you?

The demand and the money is a big attraction for some but you must understand there is a huge amount of responsibility in being a QP, could you cope if you made the wrong decision and 100 people died?

There are good parts to being a QP and there are the tedious parts, you must be willing to do them all to protect the patient.

Read the study guide, talk to QPs who are on a licence now, find out what it really means.



Thank you for reading!

Being a Pharmaceutical Qualified Person is something I obsess over.

Make sure to follow me @paulrpalmer for more on the role of the Qualified Person.

commentary.text: Your Dad was a star Mark. We are thinking of you all at this difficult time.
It doesn't matter if it is SOPs, test methods, Regulations or any similar document, they should all be referred to on a regular basis instead of being treated as a memory challenge.

There are times at work when you absolutely need to be at 100%, in my industry "Pharmaceutical Manufacturing" patients lives are dependent on it. However, you cannot be at 100% at work without a happy home life that includes rest and relaxation. Sometimes if you are feeling overburdened at work and moving towards burnout the best thing to do is to take a break. It can be a cup of tea, a 20 minute walk, some annual leave, or anything in between. 
There are absolutely times when you simply need to get the head down and work hard, but there are also times when that is absolutely the wrong thing to do.

It is important to remember that in QA you are generally part of the QA team, which is part of the Quality team, which is part of the site team, which is part of the company team. When we all work together and help each other towards the same goals, in the same priority order, things go an awful lot smoother than when we work against each other. Share the workload as appropriate and spend the most time on the things that are truly important.

This can be difficult though as it is not everyone who can objectively look at their own health issues and consider if they are related to work. It is also often more effective to react to the types of early warning signs that our family and friends would pick up on before us like irritability, inability to switch off from work or just being emotionally distant.
It has long been said, that the time to worry in business is when your most passionate people go quiet. Burnout can be one of the causes for that to happen.
I hope that it is a fantastic position for you Pamela!
I thoroughly enjoyed that Yan, another very informative webinar from the team!
It is also "International Laboratory Day", did St. George run an international network of labs?

If it can help us to develop medicines that are more effective, safer, more consistent, whilst also making the manufacture, testing and reviewing processes more efficient, why wouldn't companies move towards the AI world?
I hope that you and your family enjoy your celebrations Adil!
Dr Vanessa C. "The odious member for the 18th century" 😂 🤣
